start.title:
Geometric Truths

The Foundations of Geometry in Ancient Alexandria
start.description: At the Great Library of Alexandria, Hypatia helps a young architect discover how practical constructions  lead to understanding the beautiful, timeless nature of geometry itself.

S2_D1_F4_C0.heading: Welcome to Library of Alexandria
S2_D1_F4_C0.body:
Almost 3,500 years after the construction of the Great Pyramid of Giza, another great edifice was constructed in Egypt: The Great Library of Alexandria.

For nearly 600 years, scholars labored away to discover new forms of wisdom and beauty. They worked to discover—and rediscover—the secrets of geometry. And with these secrets, they accomplished wonders: from calculating the size of the Earth to developing mechanical computers that could track the motion of planets.

Our story begins 1,650 years ago, in the year 380, when a young architect seeks out practical wisdom from Hypatia, one of the most famous mathematical philosophers of all time.

S3.S3_D1_FX_C3: It has been nearly 600 years since Euclid worked in the great library, preparing his Elements of Geometry.
S3.S3_D2_FX_C2: Yet, geometry is more ancient still. For Pythagoras, we know, learned from the Egyptians.
S3.S3_D3_FX_C3: Geometry is beautiful knowledge, for even if its books are destroyed, it can be discovered again—the wisdom of mathematics is timeless and eternal.
S3.S3_D4_FX_C1: But can you really discover mathematics?
S3.S3_D5_FX_C2: Akila, you always ask such wonderful questions. What brings you here today?
S3.S3_D6_FX_C1: I have some architectural problems and I was hoping you might reveal some of your geometrical secrets.
S3.S3_D7_FX_C2: I am always happy to share.
S3.S3_D8_FX_C1: I am trying to find the middle of the circle — the exact center. I am sure there is some way to measure it, but I can't seem to get it right.
S3.S3_D9_FX_C1: I also need to place a temple column exactly in between two other columns. However, I can't seem to get the measurements exactly right. No matter how carefully I measure, there's always some small difference. Could the wisdom of geometry help me?
S3.S3_D10_FX_C2: I would be happy to help you, Akila. And we won't need to measure at all. Instead, we can use geometric construction to find the middle.

about.heading: Circle Construction with a Compass
about.body:
The key properties demonstrated in this interactive:

  1. Definition: A circle is the set of all points in a plane that are equidistant from a given point (center A).
  2. Compass Function: The compass maintains a fixed radius as it rotates around the center point.

In this interactive, you will:

  • Use a compass tool to trace a perfect circle around the established center point
  • See how the constant radius creates a perfect circle where all points are equidistant from the center

help.heading: Need Help?
help.body:
How to Use the Interactive:

  1. Observe the Center: The interactive starts with point A established as the center.
  2. Place the Compass: Drag the compass tool onto the canvas to set up construction.
  3. Trace the Circle: Click the 'Trace' button to watch the compass draw a perfect circle.

Things to Observe:

  • Notice how the compass maintains a fixed distance from the center as it traces the circle
  • See how every point on the completed circle is exactly the same distance from center A

S4.S4_D1_FX_C2: Let's start by constructing a circle, where we know the middle: here, point A.
S4.S4_D2_FX_C2:
Now, a compass will ensure that a line is drawn at an equal distance from this center point.

You can drag the compass to the canvas on the left, or click the "Place Compass" button to place it automatically.
S4.S4_D3_FX_C2: Now, use this compass to trace a circle around the center point.
S4.S4_D4_FX_C2: Do you see that every point on the circle is exactly the same distance from the center? That's what defines the idea of a circle!
S4.S4_D5_FX_C1: Yes, the compass keeps the distance fixed.
S4.S4_D6_FX_C2: Akila — can you tell me, in your own words: what is it that defines a circle?
S4.S4_D6_FX_C9_optionB: A set of points all the same distance from a center point
S4.S4_D6_FX_C9_optionD: A line that goes through the center of a square
S4.S4_D7_FX_C1: Of course! It's all the points that are the same distance from the center.
S4.S4_D8_FX_C2: Exactly. That's the heart of the circle's definition.
S4.S4_D9_FX_C3: But remember — the circle we drew here is only an approximation. The mathematical idea of a circle has no thickness — and is perfectly round.
S4.S4_D10_FX_C1: Wait... are you saying this isn't a perfect circle? Even though we used a compass?
S4.S4_D11_FX_C3:
Good question. Let me ask you this:
Do you think it's possible to draw a perfect circle with our tools?
S4.S4_D11_FX_C9_optionA: Yes, a compass draws a perfect circle
S4.S4_D11_FX_C9_optionB: No, tools can never make a mathematically perfect circle
S4.S4_D11_FX_C9_optionC: Yes, if you use an extremely precise compass
S4.S4_D11_FX_C9_optionD: No, perfect circles only exist in imagination
S4.S4_D12_FX_C1: Ah — I see. The compass helps us approximate a perfect circle, but the true one only exists in mathematics.
S4.S4_D13_FX_C3: Exactly. It's the idea of the circle that is perfect — not the drawing itself.

S5.S5_D1_F20_C1:
Ok, but this circle we already know the center — we needed that to draw it.
What if I've lost track of the center? Can I ever really find it again?
S5.S5_D2_F21_C2: Yes, there are ways. Let's start by using two circles to find the exact middle of a line.
S5.S5_D3_F22_C1: That's easy, I can just measure the whole line and divide it in half.

about.heading: Intersection Properties
about.body:
When two circles of equal radius intersect:

  • Their intersection points are equidistant from both centers
  • This construction guarantees perfect midpoint location without measurement

In this interactive, you will:

  • Create two circles with equal radii
  • Observe their intersection points
  • Discover how these points help find the midpoint
  • Understand why this construction must work

help.heading: Need Help?
help.body:
How to Use the Interactive:

  1. Set First Center: Click to place the center of your first circle (Point A).
  2. Set Second Center: Click to place the center of your second circle (Point B).
  3. Adjust Position: Move the circles by clicking and dragging the center in a way that both circles intersect.

Things to Observe:

  • Notice how the intersection points (C and D) are always equidistant from both centers
  • Watch how moving the circles maintains this equidistant property
  • See how the perpendicular bisector always crosses AB at its midpoint M

S6.S6_D0_F23_C2:
True! But let me show you another way.
Let's draw a circle at point A.
S6.S6_D1_F27_C1: But what do circles have to do with finding the middle point?
S6.S6_D2_F28_C2:
Remember what defines a circle, we just learned that every point on a circle is equidistant from its center.

Now, draw another circle at B, with the same radius, and try to drag them around. Tell me, what happens when the two circles meet?
S6.S6_D4_F30_C2: Yes! Let's call these intersection points C and D. Try moving your circles — see how these intersection points change, yet they always remain equidistant from both centers?
S6.S6_D5_F31_C1:
It looks like C is equally distant from point A and point B.
That's what I'm looking for:
a point that is in the middle of A & B.
S6.S6_D6_F32_C2: It does look like C is equidistant from both centers, A and B. But how do you know?
S6.S6_D7_F33_C1:
Well, the point C lies on each of their circles. And every point on a circle is the same distance from its center. And, these circles are the same size.
So actually, point D must also be equidistant from both A and B for the same reason!
S6.S6_D8_F34_C1: But they aren't on the line—aren't we trying to find the midpoint of the line?
S6.S6_D9_F35_C2:
Yes, so now, draw a line between points C and D.
Do you see how this line CD intersects line AB?
At that intersection, let's make a point M.
S6.S6_D10_F36_C1: It looks like it is exactly in the middle of the points A and B.
S6.S6_D11_F37_C2: M does look like the midpoint. But, can you know for sure?
S6.S6_D12_F38_C1:
M is no longer on either circle. But maybe if I move the circles further apart, I could put M at the edge of each circle?
Then, if it is on both circles, then I know it is exactly the same distance from the centers.
S6.S6_D13_F39_C2:
That is a creative proof! Yes, in that way, you can show that M can be equidistant from A and B.

Wonderful, now you have used geometry to find the exact middle point of a line—and you never had to measure anything!

about.heading: Finding Circle Centers
about.body:
To find the center of any circle using geometric construction:

  • Draw any line (chord) across the circle
  • Find the perpendicular bisector of that chord
  • Draw a second chord and find its perpendicular bisector
  • Where the two perpendicular bisectors intersect is the exact center

In this Interactive, You Will:

  1. Observe a circle whose center is unknown
  2. See how a blue line is drawn across the circle
  3. Watch the red perpendicular bisector of the blue line appear
  4. Observe a green line drawn across the circle
  5. See the red perpendicular bisector of the green line
  6. Discover the center where the two red bisectors intersect

help.heading: Need Help?
help.body:
How to Use the Interactive:

  1. Follow the Steps:

    The construction happens automatically as you progress through the dialog.

  2. Observe the Process:

    Watch how each step builds on the previous to find the center.

  3. Focus on Elements:

    Click or tab through different parts of the construction to highlight them.

Why This Works:

  • Every perpendicular bisector of a chord passes through the circle's center
  • Two different bisectors can only intersect at one point: the center
  • This method works for any circle, regardless of size

S7.S7_D1_F35_C1: Now can you tell me how to find the center of a circle?
S7.S7_D2_F36_C2: Yes! We can use the midpoint finding method we just learned, but we need to build upon it cleverly.
S7.S7_D4_F38_C2: We start by having any line across the circle. Here's our first blue line - this is called a 'chord.'
S7.S7_D5_F39_C1: I see the blue chord goes right across the circle! But this doesn't seem to pass anywhere near the center.
S7.S7_D6_F40_C2: That's perfectly fine! The chord can be anywhere in the circle - it doesn't need to pass through the center.
S7.S7_D7_F41_C2: Now find the perpendicular bisector of this blue chord, using the same method we learned before. You can toggle the construction circles to see how perpendicular bisector was built.
S7.S7_D8_F42_C1: I can see the red perpendicular bisector! But how does this help us find the center?
S7.S7_D9_F43_C2: This red line must pass through the center, because the center is equidistant from all points on the circle, including our chord endpoints.
S7.S7_D10_F44_C1: That makes sense, but we still don't know exactly where on the red line the center is.
S7.S7_D11_F45_C2: Exactly! So we need another clue. Here is our second green line across the circle.
S7.S7_D12_F46_C1: Now we have both blue and green chords on the circle.
S7.S7_D13_F47_C2: Now find the perpendicular bisector of this green chord too.
S7.S7_D14_F48_C1: I see the perpendicular bisector! And I can toggle the construction on and off for this one too.
S7.S7_D15_F49_C2: Great! Now can you think how having these 2 perpendicular bisectors helps us?
S7.S7_D16_F50_C1: Well, they both intersect each other. Can that be our center?
S7.S7_D17_F51_C2: Correct! The reason behind it is that both perpendicular bisectors must pass through the center, because the center is equidistant from all points on the circle. So their intersection point is the center.
S7.S7_D18_F52_C1: Great! And we never had to measure anything!

S8.S8_D2_F49_C3: But remember, any circle you draw is only an approximation of a real circle. Your lines will never be perfectly round—and they will always have thickness. Yet the idea of a true circle is perfect, timeless —and very real.
S8.S8_D3_F50_C3: It is true that math is an eternal and timeless structure of our world. Even the pyramids will eventually wear down into dust. Yet geometry is built of eternal mathematical truths.
S8.S8_D4_F51_C1: Isn't the idea of a circle just an image in our minds?
S8.S8_D6_F53_C2: Or perhaps our minds discover something that already exists. Perhaps circles are deeply real—but the idea of them can be discovered, like an explorer finding a new land.
S8.S8_D7_F54_C1: How beautiful that people might explore. What a beautiful idea, that mathematics is made of timeless truths—and that people can explore it to discover new truths. Can you share another construction?
S8.S8_D8_F55_C2: Yes. The first construction in Euclid's Elements of Geometry is about the creation of a triangle with 3 equal sides: an equilateral triangle.

S9.S9_D1_F52_C3: I tell you, these are the mysteries that fascinated the Pythagoreans.
S9.S9_D2_F53_C1: I know the Pythagorean Theorem. Is that what you mean?
S9.S9_D3_F54_C3: Yes, Pythagoras was a great mathematician—Euclid owes much to his discoveries. Pythagoras taught that the whole cosmos is made of mathematics—even that mathematics is a more basic element of nature than water or air!
S9.S9_D4_F55_C2: And not only did he think the world was made of math, but that there are harmonies in mathematics.
S9.S9_D5_F56_C1: Please, I'd love to hear these harmonies.
S9.S9_D6_F57_C3: These geometric harmonies must be experienced through the mind, not through the ears.
S9.S9_D7_F58_C2: Truly, just with a <no-glossary>series</no-glossary> of circles and lines—we can produce a kind of harmony: A perfectly balanced equilateral triangle.
S9.S9_D8_F59_C2: For this, we start with two circles with the same radius. Then, simply draw the center of one circle anywhere on the line of the other circle.

S10_D0_F76_C9.title: Equilateral Triangle Construction

about.heading: Triangle Properties
about.body:
When two circles pass through each other's centers:

  • Connecting the two center points to either of the two intersection points will create an equilateral triangle
  • All sides of the triangle are radii of the circles, ensuring equality
  • This construction relies purely on geometric principles without measurement

In this Interactive, You Will:

  1. Observe two circles: one centered at Point A passing through Point B, and another green circle centered at Point B passing through Point A.
  2. Identify the intersection point C of the two circles.
  3. Connect this intersection point to Points A and B to form the equilateral triangle.
  4. Observe why this construction guarantees equal sides for the triangle.

help.heading: Need Help?
help.body:
How to Use the Interactive:

  1. Identify Intersection:

    Observe the intersection point of the two circles.

  2. Complete the Triangle:

    Click to connect Points A, B, and the intersection point C to form the triangle.

S10_D0_F76_C9.controllsNote: Drag the center points or select the center points then use arrow keys to explore the construction.

S10.S10_D1_F55_C1: I see: the circle centered at point A goes through point B, and the circle centered at point B goes through point A.
S10.S10_D2_F56_C2: Exactly. Now, you can drag points A or B to explore different configurations. Do you see how the lines connect between the center of the circles and their intersections?
S10.S10_D3_F57_C1: It's a perfect triangle! From point A to B to C!
S10.S10_D4_F58_C2: Yes, both circles have the same sized radius. What else do you notice about the lines?
S10.S10_D5_F59_C1: Well, the distance from A to C is also the radius of A. And the distance from B to C is the radius of B...
S10.S10_D6_F60_C2: And what's special about these three line segments?
S10.S10_D7_F61_C1: Well, they must all be the same size, because the radius of each circle is the same. So we've made an equilateral triangle!
S10.S10_D8_F62_C2: And this will always work, regardless of how large we make our circles, as long as…
S10.S10_D9_F63_C1:
As long as we keep those two conditions:
Same radius for both circles, and each circle passing through the other's center!

S11.S11_D1_F66_C2: You see, from a few simple and precise definitions, you've created geometric constructions that define circles, midpoints and equilateral triangles.  And all without measurement.
S11.S11_D2_F67_C1: It is beautiful that these purely mathematical beings—circles and lines—can come together and produce a kind of harmony—this perfectly balanced triangle!
S11.S11_D3_F68_C3:
The philosopher Plato taught that, when we study geometry, we're training our minds to reason and recognize truths.
He encouraged us to discover the timeless forms behind the material world.
S11.S11_D4_F69_C1: I know that anything I build will have some imperfection—and it won't last forever. But, with geometry, the ideas are so timeless!
S11.S11_D5_F70_C2:
Geometry is useful for construction and design. Yes. But it can also lead to profound ideas. Like that mathematics creates harmony. Or that the physical world is brimming with geometry.
For instance, did you know that there is a geometry to the planets above? With these secrets of geometry, I've even designed a machine that can track the stars and calculate the time!
S11.S11_D6_F71_C1: Hypatia, thank you! Your wisdom is both practical and profound.

quest_completion.subheading: You've explored the wisdom within the foundations of geometry!
quest_completion.content:
You successfully completed the Geometric Truths STEAMQuest.

  • You developed the art of geometric construction using circles and a compass
  • You connected mathematical principles to practical architectural challenges
  • You learned to find the midpoint of a line, the center of a circle
  • You learned to construct a perfect equilateral triangle, without measurement

Keep exploring the beautiful and timeless nature of geometric principles!

geometric_necessity.definition: Geometric Necessity is when something must be true because of what it is, not because we measured it.

perpendicular_bisector.definition: Perpendicular Bisector is a line that cuts another line segment into two equal parts at right angles.

perpendicular_bisectors.definition: Perpendicular Bisector is a line that cuts another line segment into two equal parts at right angles.

equidistant.definition: Equidistant means being exactly the same distance from two or more points.

radius.definition: Radius is the fixed distance from the center of a circle to any point on its circumference.

congruent_triangles.definition: Congruent Triangles are two triangles that match exactly in all their parts (sides and angles).

construction.definition: Construction is using a compass and straightedge to create geometric figures with utmost precision.

constructions.definition: Construction is using a compass and straightedge to create geometric figures with utmost precision.

intersection_point.definition: Intersection Points are points where two geometric figures (like circles) meet.

intersection_points.definition: Intersection Points are points where two geometric figures (like circles) meet.

geometric_proof.definition: Geometric Proof is a logical argument showing why a geometric statement must be true.

physical_tool.definition: Physical Tool is an actual instrument like a compass, which may be imperfect.

physical_tools.definition: Physical Tools are actual instruments like compasses, which can wear or be imperfect.

mathematical_truth.definition: Mathematical Truth is a perfect concept that exists in the realm of pure geometry, independent of physical representations.

common.akila_description: Akila, an Egyptian architecture student with wavy dark hair wearing a white draped tunic and holding scrolls.
common.hypatia_description: Hypatia, historical mathematician and teacher from Alexandria, with elegant hairstyle in blue and white robes with gold embellishments.
common.theon_description: Theon, senior mathematician and Hypatia's father, elderly bearded man in classical robes holding a scroll of Euclid's Elements.
common.bg1_description: Panoramic view of ancient Alexandria from a columned portico, showing the Great Library complex with its obelisk, harbor with ships, and distant mountains under a blue sky at sunset.
common.bg2_description: Interior of an Egyptian temple or educational hall with massive hieroglyph-covered columns, showing scholars and students in white robes studying at tables, with bright desert landscape and mountains visible through the colonnade.
common.bg3_description: Sunlit circular study chamber in Alexandria's Library with drafting tables, scrolls, and architectural tools, featuring stone columns framing views of the Mediterranean Sea, harbor, and distant mountains.
common.bg4_description: Mathematical study room in ancient Alexandria with a large drafting table displaying astronomical and geometric diagrams, surrounded by columns with panoramic views of the Mediterranean coastline at sunset.
common.bg5_description: Interior of the Great Library of Alexandria with towering columns, rows of scrolls in shelves, silhouettes of scholars studying at tables, and wide openings revealing the coastline and Egyptian landscape bathed in golden sunset light.
